spanishExample: ¡Ah! Hay un par aquí.
englishTranslation: Ah! There are a couple here.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: ¡Claro! Cuanto menos hagas, mejor.
englishTranslation: Of course! The less you do, the better.

spanishExample: ¡Claro! Si debemos hacerlo, vamos a ir.
englishTranslation: Of course! If we must do it, we are going to go.
vocabIncluded: debemos:must, we must (Deber, present, 1st person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ay, ya sé que es el fin para ellos.
englishTranslation: Yikes, now I know it’s the end for them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Bueno, ese no fue el mejor final.
englishTranslation: All right, that wasn’t the best ending.

spanishExample: Cuanto más hace, más debe hacer.
englishTranslation: The more he does, the more he must do.
vocabIncluded: debe: must, he/she/it must (Deber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Dale, debemos decirle.
englishTranslation: Go ahead, we must tell her.
vocabIncluded: debemos:must, we must (Deber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Dale, tienes que decirle que debe ir.
englishTranslation: Go ahead, you have to tell her she must go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
debe: must, he/she/it must (Deber, present, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Debemos darle cuanto tiempo quiera.
englishTranslation: We must give him as much time as he wants.
vocabIncluded: cuanto used with a subjunctive to mean "as much as", as in “cuanto quiera” (pronoun)
debemos:must, we must (Deber, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Debemos ir si ellos no van a hacerlo.
englishTranslation: We must go if they are not going to do it.
vocabIncluded: debemos:must, we must (Deber, present, 1st person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Deben hacer cuanto trabajo puedan.
englishTranslation: They must do as much work as they can.
vocabIncluded: cuanto used with a subjunctive to mean "as much as", as in “cuanto quiera” (pronoun)
deben: must, they must (Deber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Debes hacer lo que ellos te dicen.
englishTranslation: You must do what they tell you.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
debes: must, you must (Deber, present, 2nd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Debo ir a clase ahora.
englishTranslation: I must go to class now.
vocabIncluded: debo: must, I must (Deber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Debo tener unos cuantos amigos.
englishTranslation: I must have a small number of friends.
vocabIncluded: debo: must, I must (Deber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Debo ver lo que están haciendo.
englishTranslation: I must see what they are doing.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
debo: must, I must (Deber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Eh, no debes decirle el final.
englishTranslation: Hmm, you mustn’t tell him the ending.
vocabIncluded: debes: must, you must (Deber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ellos deben estar aquí y debemos estar con ellos.
englishTranslation: They must be here and we must be with them.
vocabIncluded: debemos:must, we must (Deber, present, 1st person plural)
deben: must, they must (Deber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Ellos deben ir, y por esa razón tú también debes ir.
englishTranslation: They must go, and for that reason, you also must go.
vocabIncluded: deben: must, they must (Deber, present, 3rd person plural)
debes: must, you must (Deber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: En cuanto a eso, en verdad debe hacerlo.
englishTranslation: Regarding that, he must actually do it.
vocabIncluded: debe: must, he/she/it must (Deber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Lo que dices no va a pasar si no haces un par de cosas antes.
englishTranslation: What you’re saying is not going to happen if you don’t do a couple of things first.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Me dijo que debo estar ahí a esa hora.
englishTranslation: He told me I must be there at that time.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
debo: must, I must (Deber, present, 1st person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: No puedes estar en el medio, debes irte.
englishTranslation: You can’t be in the middle, you must leave.
vocabIncluded: debes: must, you must (Deber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Pues, sabes que debe hacerlo.
englishTranslation: Well, you know he must do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
debe: must, he/she/it must (Deber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Sabemos que unos cuantos hombres van a pasar por su casa.
englishTranslation: We know that a small number of men are going to pass by their house.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
